title: AB 2687
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. Blood alcohol concentration is measured in grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. In California, driving with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher is prohibited under Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code. It is also unlawful for a person addicted to drugs to drive, except for those in approved narcotic treatment programs. It is illegal to drive a commercial motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, with a rebuttable presumption if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows the same alcohol level. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is present. A passenger for hire is defined as someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. In a prosecution, it is assumed the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if proven by a chemical test within three hours after driving. Driving with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood is illegal, especially when a passenger for hire is present. This is determined by a chemical test within three hours after driving. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to others. It is unlawful to drive with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more and cause bodily injury to someone else. There is a rebuttable presumption if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more. In proving negligence in driving, it is not necessary to show a specific violation of the law. It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, leading to bodily injury to others. A chemical test within three hours can be used as evidence. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and the driver's actions cause bodily injury to someone else. A passenger for hire is defined as someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. It is illegal to drive a vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is present and bodily injury is caused. A rebuttable presumption exists if a chemical test shows 0.04% or more alcohol within three hours of driving. It is unlawful to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to someone other than the driver. No reimbursement required by this act as it creates, eliminates, or changes penalties for crimes or infractions, per Section 17556 of the Government Code and Section 6 of Article XIII B of the California Constitution.
